title: Johann Christoph Friedrich Klug
text:
Johann Christoph Friedrich Klug (5 May 1775, in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a> – 3 February 1856, in Berlin), was a German <a href="entomologist">entomologist</a>.
He described the <a href="butterflies">butterflies</a> and some other insects of <a href="Egypt">Upper Egypt</a> and <a href="Arabia">Arabia</a> in <a href="Christian%20Gottfried%20Ehrenberg">Christian Gottfried Ehrenberg</a> and <a href="Wilhelm%20Friedrich%20Hemprich">Wilhelm Friedrich Hemprich</a>'s "Symbolæ Physicæ" (Berlin, 1829–1845). He was professor of <a href="medicine">medicine</a> and entomology in the University of Berlin (known in the present day as the <a href="Humboldt%20University%20of%20Berlin">Humboldt University of Berlin</a>) where he curated the insect collections from 1810 to 1856. At the same time he directed the <a href="Botanical%20Garden%20in%20Berlin">Botanic Garden in Berlin</a> which contains his collections. Klug worked mainly on <a href="Hymenoptera">Hymenoptera</a> and <a href="Coleoptera">Coleoptera</a>. The plant genus "<a href="Klugia">Klugia</a>" (now called "<a href="Rhynchoglossum">Rhynchoglossum</a>", Family <a href="Gesneriaceae">Gesneriaceae</a>) was named in his honour as well as the butterflies "<a href="Geitoneura%20klugii">Geitoneura klugii</a>" and "<a href="Heliophisma%20klugii">Heliophisma klugii</a>".
In 1855, he was elected a foreign member of the <a href="Royal%20Swedish%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences</a>.
